thread.title: Sano named Twins MVP by baseball writers
thread.title_full: Sano named Twins MVP by baseball writers

title: Sano named Twins MVP by baseball writers
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Sano named Twins MVP by baseball writers Despite playing in less than half of his team's games in 2015, Twins rookie slugger Miquel Sano is honored as the club's Most Valuable Player by the Twin Cities Baseball Writers Association. Post to Facebook Sano named Twins MVP by baseball writers Despite playing in less than half of his team's games in 2015, Twins rookie slugger Miquel Sano is honored as the club's Most Valuable Player by the Twin Cities Baseball Writers Association.   kare11.com: http://www.kare11.com/story/sports/mlb/twins/2015/10/20/sano-named-twins-mvp-by-baseball-writers/74271416/   Join the Conversation To   Sano named Twins MVP by baseball writers Dana Thiede, KARE 1 p.m. EDT October 20, 2015 Sep 2, 2015; Minneapolis, MN, USA; Minnesota Twins designated hitter Miguel Sano (22) celebrates his solo home run during the second inning against the Chicago White Sox at Target Field. (Photo: Marilyn Indahl-USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
MINNEAPOLIS - Despite playing in less than half of his team's games in 2015, Twins rookie slugger Miquel Sano is honored as the club's Most Valuable Player by the Twin Cities Baseball Writers Association. 
Sano, who also won outstanding Twins rookie honors, appeared in just 80 of 162 games, batting .269 (75-for-279) with 17 doubles, one triple, 18 home runs and 52 RBI. His 18 home runs finished eighth on the Twins all-time list for rookies, and ranked second among AL rookies and fifth among MLB rookies. 
Sep 1, 2015; Minneapolis, MN, USA; Minnesota Twins designated hitter Miguel Sano (22) hits a single in the second inning against the Chicago White Sox at Target Field. (Photo: Jesse Johnson-USA TODAY Sports) 
Below is the complete list of winners. RHP Kyle Gibson is the winner of the Joseph W. Haynes Award (Former Twins Executive Vice President) given to the Twins Pitcher of the Year. Gibson started a team-high 32 games this season, posting a 3.84 ERA while leading the team with a career-high 145 strikeouts and 194.2 innings pitched. Gibson ranked fourth in all of baseball with 27 double plays induced OF Torii Hunter is the winner of the of the Bob Allison Award (Former Twins Player) given to the Twins player who exemplifies determination, hustle, tenacity, competitive spirit and leadership both on and off the field. He is also awarded the Mike Augustin "Media Good Guy" Award (Former Pioneer Press Sports Writer). Hunter appeared in 139 games, posting a .240 (125-for-521) batting average with 22 doubles, 22 home runs and 81 RBI. Hunter, along with his wife Katrina, remain very active with the Boys & Girls Clubs of the Twin Cities. OF Aaron Hicks is the winner of the Charles O. Johnson Award (Former Minneapolis Star Tribune Sports Editor) given to the Twins Most Improved Player. He recorded career-highs in games (97), runs (48), hits (90), home runs (11), RBI (33), stolen bases (13) and batting average (.256). OF Eddie Rosario is the winner of the Jim Kaat Award (Former Twins Pitcher) for Twins Defensive Player of the Year. Rosario played in 122 games, committing just seven errors in 243 total chances. His 16 outfield assists were most among baseball rookies, second most in the AL and tied for second most in all of baseball. 2B Brian Dozier is the winner of the Carl R. Pohlad Community Service Award. Dozier appeared in 157 games, posting a .236 (148-for-628) batting average with 39 doubles, four triples, and 28 home runs. Dozier established a community ticket program called Dozier's Heroes that provides Twins tickets to just returning military service members and their families. Along with his wife, Renee, Brian also works with Amigos for Christ, an organization helping to build schools and clean water systems in Central American countries. 
The awards will be officially handed out at the Eleventh Annual Diamond Awards dinner, set for Thursday, January 28, 2016 at Target Field. All proceeds from the event will benefit the University of Minnesota's innovative research and patient care focused on ALS (Lou Gehrig's Disease), ataxia, muscular dystrophy, multiple sclerosis and Parkinson's disease. Corporate sponsorship opportunities, tables and individual tickets are now available. For more information on the event visit minnesotadiamondawards.org or call (612) 625-7490.
